channel.title: Logarithms (and maybe some Algorithms)
channel.description:
This week in my Discrete Structures module we've been doing Matrice's, Logs, and Algorithm. I really really can't seem to get the hang of Logs or Algorithms at all, and was hoping someone would be able to provide me with some methods for working them out as I have a test tomorrow (I'm not using your answers for a worksheet).
I can do very basic logs e.g log[sub]2[/sub](16) = 4 log[sub]4[/sub](2x32) = 3
but where I'm really struggling is for logs with fractions and other functions in. for example: log[sub]121[/sub](11) log[sub]2[/sub](1/8) log[sub]4[/sub](1/2) 4[sup]log[sub]2[/sub][/sup][sup](3)[/sup]
Any methods for working out any of the above and I would be so so grateful.
Likewise, an example question for this test is: How many steps would a binary search take on a sorted list of 1000?
A student is given a list of six projects to choose from and has to list them in descending order of preference. How many possibilities are there for such a list?
With Algorithms I'm really just looking for any sort of explaination as to what they are/how they work, but I probably wont even attempt the Qs on the test.
Really bad at maths.
Thanks to anyone that helps.

[quote=“Jc22493, post:21, topic:369226”][quote author=la­wl link=topic=465360.msg3416201#msg3416201 date=1291084319]

saying that the ! comes after 5 because it reads ‘five factorial’ is like saying $ should come after 5 because it reads ‘5 dollars’

your logic is fail

Lol’d. l2commonsense again.
[/quote]He’s saying that your reason I was incorrect made no sense, because it doesn’t matter how you say it.

eh don’t bother hes not going to get it anytime soon

You’re so smart. canutaechme[/quote]

Way to completely go off topic. Kudos, have some points.

item.title: Logarithms (and maybe some Algorithms)
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

Mr.Chris:

How many steps would a binary search take on a sorted list of 1000?

in worst case, log[sub]2[/sub] 1000
because it cuts the list in half every time

Mr.Chris:

A student is given a list of six projects to choose from and has to list them in descending order of preference. How many possibilities are there for such a list?

edit: nvm im wrong cant think right now !! someone else answer this
prolly something like 2^6 though

Read full topic

[quote=“Mr.Chris, post:7, topic:369226”]Nevermind, slept through my fucking alarm and missed the test anyway. Thanks anyway though![/quote]Lol, you will still eventually have to take it right?

Just write down:
log[sub]b/sub = x
b[sup]x[/sup] = y

item.title: Logarithms (and maybe some Algorithms)
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Mr.Chris, post:3, topic:369226”]Thanks for that. I got the 1/8 one, but I’m struggling to understand the long121(11) - I’m not too sure where the 1/2 comes from?[/quote]Because 121^(.5) = 11

You’re basically working backwards.

log[sub]b/sub = x
b[sup]x[/sup] = y

log[sub]121/sub = x
121[sup]x[/sup] = 11
121[sup].5[/sup] = 11

Read full topic

item.title: Logarithms (and maybe some Algorithms)
item.dc:creator: @Mr.Chris Mr.Chris
item.description:
@Mr.Chris wrote:

Thanks for that. I got the 1/8 one, but I’m struggling to understand the long121(11) - I’m not too sure where the 1/2 comes from?

Read full topic

item.title: Logarithms (and maybe some Algorithms)
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

“A student is given a list of six projects to choose from and has to list them in descending order of preference. How many possibilities are there for such a list?”
n!, where n is number of project.
Why: First the student have 6 projects to choose from, for the second on the list he have 5 projects…

“log121(11)”
You know how log works right?
For what power of 121 gives you 11? That will be 1/2, since (x^1/2) = sqrt(x)
log2(1/8)
For this. 2^-3 = 1/2^3 = 1/8
For that reason log2(1/8) is -3.

Hope you understand a little…

Read full topic

item.title: Logarithms (and maybe some Algorithms)

item.description:
@Mr.Chris wrote:

This week in my Discrete Structures module we’ve been doing Matrice’s, Logs, and Algorithm. I really really can’t seem to get the hang of Logs or Algorithms at all, and was hoping someone would be able to provide me with some methods for working them out as I have a test tomorrow (I’m not using your answers for a worksheet).

I can do very basic logs e.g
log[sub]2/sub = 4
log[sub]4/sub = 3

but where I’m really struggling is for logs with fractions and other functions in. for example:
log[sub]121/sub
log[sub]2/sub
log[sub]4/sub
4[sup]log[sub]2[/sub][/sup]sup[/sup]

Any methods for working out any of the above and I would be so so grateful.

Likewise, an example question for this test is:
How many steps would a binary search take on a sorted list of 1000?

A student is given a list of six projects to choose from and has to list them in descending order of preference. How many possibilities are there for such a list?

With Algorithms I’m really just looking for any sort of explaination as to what they are/how they work, but I probably wont even attempt the Qs on the test.

Really bad at maths.
